Graphical abstract A series of titania-supported transition metal oxide catalysts were evaluated for NO reduction with CO as reductant at low temperature (200°C) in the presence of excess oxygen. Among the investigated systems, MnOx/TiO2 has been found to be the preeminent catalyst. In situ FT-IR and transient studies were carried out in order to identify the chemisorbed species which could act as catalytic intermediates, and in consequence to propose the low temperature reduction of NO pathway over the Mn/TiO2. The NO adsorption and NO+O2 co-adsorption of in situ FT-IR experiments revealed the formation of surface reaction intermediate N2O species along with the formation of monodentate and bidentate nitrates, whereas CO adsorption on the catalyst leads to the formation of carbonate species. Interestingly, in the case of NO and CO co-adsorption over MnOx/TiO2, the formation of CO2 (CO oxidation with gas phase oxygen) is inhibited due to the surface reaction competition between NO and CO. The formation of N2O as an intermediate was evident from the occurrence of peaks at 1286 and 1335cm−1 region. There is no formation of NO2 as a surface intermediate or gas phase stable product in the present in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and transient mass spectroscopic studies, respectively. Remarkably, a neat absorption peak at 2178cm−1 ascribed to the isocyanate (–NCO) species was not observed during in situ infrared spectroscopic studies of NO+CO and CO+NO co-adsorptions. Based upon this evidence it is proposed that the formation of NCO− species from the reaction between CO and Nads is completely forbidden over the Mn/TiO2 catalysts. These results indicate that the reaction mechanism follows a different pathway for our catalyst, from that of the other metal based catalysts. The role of lattice oxygen in the reaction mechanism is substantiated by isotopic labeling and transient analysis studies. Lewis acid sites act as the active sites for the reaction. Keywords Nitric oxide (NO) Carbon monoxide (CO) Manganese oxides (MnOx) In situ FT-IR Transient analysis Isotopic labeling 1 Introduction The chemistry of reducing NO to nitrogen has attracted considerable interest of many researchers due to its adverse effect on the environment. For decades, it was accomplished by using noble metal and metal oxide catalysts at elevated temperatures using reductants like NH3, urea, hydrocarbons etc. [1–3]. For economical reasons, continuous efforts were made to replace noble metal based catalysts with transition metal based catalysts and to develop catalysts capable of operating at relatively low temperatures [4]. Although NH3 is the most widely used reductant so far, recently, CO has attracted to a great extent of interest due to the socio-economic concerns associated with ammonia [5]. Using CO as reductant has several important advantages like; it can be produced onsite for the cases of coal or natural gas utilization (stationary sources), or it is part of the exhaust stream due to incomplete combustion of liquid fuels (mobile sources), thereby eliminating the costly steps of purchasing, transporting, and storing the reductant [6]. Several catalytic systems are reported for the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO, but most of them are active at relatively high temperatures (≥300°C) [7–11]. Our research findings reveal that MnO2/TiO2 is a versatile catalyst for SCR of NO with NH3 at low temperatures and industrially relevant conditions [1,12]. In view of this, we have examined several transition metal-based catalysts for SCR of NO with CO to find out the most viable catalyst system [6,8]. Moreover, the reaction mechanism, another important aspect of the process, is still a matter of great interest. There are of course discrepancies and many controversial considerations in the open literature regarding the mechanism of NO+CO reaction. Some researchers reported that over some metal based catalysts, the isocyanate (–NCO) species is the intermediate that is formed during the NO reduction by CO [13–18]. In contrast, it was also suggested that NO dissociation and the direct formation of N2 is the important step. Other reports in the open literature propose that N2O was observed as a reaction intermediate over Pt- and Rh-based catalysts [19–21]. In view of these, combined in situ FT-IR and transient analysis of products experiments were performed to elucidate the reaction mechanism for the reaction over our MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. A series of probable elementary steps were proposed as the possible mechanism for the reaction. We found that the reaction mechanism over our catalyst follows a different pathway from that of the noble metal based catalysts. Another interesting observation is that the presence of NO in the reaction mixture hinders the CO oxidation to CO2. Moreover, there is no evidence about NO2 and isocyanate (–NCO) species formation in the present study. We propose that the NO adsorption and its subsequent dissociation occur on the reduced manganese sites leads to the formation of N2O. Thereafter, N2O dissociates into molecular nitrogen and oxygen. During the process, reduced manganese sites act as the active sites for NO dissociation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Wet impregnation method was adopted to prepare a series of anatase titania (Hombikat UV 100 from Sachtleben Chemie) supported transition metal oxide (M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu; 10wt.%) catalysts. The transition metal oxides were deposited on titania using dilute solutions of their nitrate precursors. In a typical synthesis, 50ml deionized water was added to a 100ml beaker containing a measured quantity of support. The mixture was heated to 70°C under constant stirring. Then, a predetermined amount of nitrate precursor was added to the solution and the mixture was evaporated to dryness. The paste thus obtained was further dried overnight at 110°C, ground and calcined at 400°C for 2h in a continuous flow of air and at 500°C for 4h in a continuous flow of air. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 X-ray diffraction X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Siemens D500 diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source (wavelength 1.5406Å). An aluminium holder was used to support the catalyst samples. The scanning range was 5°–80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.05° and a step time of one second. The XRD phases present in the samples were identified with the help of JCPDS data files. 2.2.2 Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out from 70–900°C on a Micromeritics AutoChem 2910 instrument using 50mg of calcined catalyst. Prior to the analysis the catalysts were pretreated at 250°C for 2h in ultra high pure helium (30mlmin−1, Wright Brothers) stream. The TPR runs were carried out with a linear heating rate (10°Cmin−1) in a flow of 4% H2 in Ar (Matheson) with a flow rate of 25mlmin−1. The hydrogen consumption was measured quantitatively by a thermal conductivity detector. 2.2.3 In situ FT-IR studies FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Bio-Rad (FTS-40) spectrometer. Circular self-supporting thin wafers (8mm diameter) consisted of 8–12mg of material were used for this study. The wafers were placed in a high-temperature cell with CaF2 windows and purged with ultra high purified (UHP) grade helium (30mlmin−1, Wright Brothers) at 200°C for 2h to remove any adsorbed impurities and cooled to 50°C. The background spectra of the solids prior to gas adsorption were collected during the cooling process and subtracted from consequently recorded spectra. The atmospheric CO2 and H2O vapor are both strong IR absorbers. Both occur in air and in the optical light path and contribute to any IR absorption signal measured. For this reason, we have recorded the air spectrum by running it with no sample and stored as a BLANK spectrum. The blank spectrum and background spectrum were then subtracted by the computer program, leaving the net sample spectrum. Any suspected changes in H2O vapors and atmospheric CO2 were corrected by updating the blank spectrum at regular intervals. On the other hand, the optical path was also purged with dry air to eliminate the interferences from the large CO2 band (atmospheric) and H2O vapors and obtain more stable environment. This eliminates the necessity of correcting for the blank signal derived from impurities in the air. Afterward, CO (1% in He, Matheson), NO (2% in He, Matheson) and pure O2 (Wright Brothers) were introduced into the cell at 30mlmin−1 for 1h at 50°C to ensure complete saturation of the sample and then physisorbed gas was removed by flushing the wafer with helium for 3h at 50°C. The same procedure was followed for the adsorption of single gas and for the adsorption of multiple gases, as helium flowed for 3h at 50°C between gas adsorption steps. The FT-IR absorption spectra were collected after desorbing the adsorbed gas at temperatures ranging from 50 to 200°C in a continuous helium flow. Sixteen scans were averaged for each normalized spectrum at a resolution of 2cm−1. To get the information about the presence of different acid sites on the catalyst and their nature, NH3 (4% in He, Matheson) adsorption was also performed in similar manner. 2.3 Reaction procedure The SCR of NO with CO was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a fixed bed quartz reactor (i.d. 6mm). A measured amount of catalyst (0.1g in dry basis, 80–120mesh) was placed in the reactor in between two glass wool plugs. Oxygen (4% in He, Wright Brothers), carbon monoxide (1% in He, Matheson) and nitric oxide (2.0% in He, Matheson) were used as received. The inlet concentrations of NO and CO were 400ppm 2vol.% of oxygen was fed into the reaction stream. All the experiments were conducted at the gas hourly space velocity of 50,000h−1. The reaction temperature was measured by a type K thermocouple inserted directly into the catalyst bed. Prior to the catalytic experiments, the catalyst was activated in situ by passing (2vol.%) oxygen for 2h at reaction temperature. The reactants and products were analyzed on-line using a Quadrapole mass spectrometer (MKS PPT-RGA), and a chemiluminescence detector (Eco Physics CLD 70S). The isotopic labeling experiments were carried out to investigate the interaction of catalyst lattice oxygen with the gas phase oxygen. 150mg of the catalyst was pretreated at 200°C temperature with 2vol% of unlabeled oxygen (4% 16O2 in He, Wright Brothers) for 2h. The purpose of the pretreatment was to remove the OH-groups from the catalyst surface. Following this, the system was flushed with helium (Wright Brothers) with the flow rate of 85ml/min to remove unlabeled oxygen completely from the reactor. Thereafter, 20,000ppm of labeled oxygen (4% 18O2; 99atom% in He, Isotech) was introduced to the system at 200°C and the a.m.u. for 16O2 (32), 16O18O (34), and 18O2 (36) were followed with a mass spectrometer (MKS PPT-RGA). The signal of the cross labeled oxygen (16O18O) was corrected from the interference with the labeled oxygen. The normalized concentrations were calculated by dividing the partial pressure of the each species by the sum of the partial pressures of all species of the same type. 3 Results and discussion The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of various titania supported transition metal oxide samples calcined at 500°C are shown in Fig. 1 . Broad diffraction lines due to the titania anatase phase (JCPDS file no. 21–1272) could be observed from the patterns. This indicates that the active metal oxides are well dispersed on the titania support, and they are in amorphous or poorly crystalline state. However, low intensity copper oxide lines are observed in the XRD pattern of Cu/TiO2, indicating the presence of crystalline copper oxide in the sample. It is interesting to note that there is no anatase to rutile phase transformation in the presence of the active metal oxides. The SCR of NO with CO at 200°C over all the prepared catalysts was performed and the activity results are presented in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from Fig. 2, under identical operating conditions, the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst is a far better catalyst compared to the other systems exhibiting higher than 90% NO conversion even in the presence of oxygen and at relatively high space velocity of 50,000h−1. We have already reported that MnOx/TiO2 catalyst leads to 100% NO conversion and N2 selectivity at low temperatures (175°C) when ammonia was used as the reductant [1,12]. Moreover, stable activity of the catalyst was found even in the presence of 2vol.% oxygen and 10vol.% water vapor in the feed [12,22]. The existence of variable oxidation states of manganese (MnO2, Mn2O3, Mn3O4 and MnO) is known to be the key factor for such high activity of Mn-based catalyst [23,24]. In order to gain better understanding about the reduction behavior of the catalytic system, the temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was carried out. As we have reported earlier, a low temperature reduction peak in TPR profile of the Mn/TiO2 sample at 325°C reveals the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3. It is known that at low loadings, manganese enters into the titania lattice [22]. Therefore, reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ may also contribute to this peak. However, in the present study reduction of titania support was observed. This is due to the interaction between support and dispersed promoter oxide by the formation of M–O-support functionalities [25,26]. It is remarkable to note that the SCR activity of our catalyst (10wt.% MnOx/TiO2) is quite high and stable even in the presence of oxygen, which is a major component in real flue gas stream. In general, earlier studies show that oxygen inhibits NO reduction with CO due to the competition between NO and oxygen for CO [27]. However, in the present study, we observed that the reaction of NO with CO reaction is highly selective over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst even in the presence of excess oxygen. Therefore, the mechanistic investigation for the reaction was carried out using this catalyst which is described in the subsequent paragraphs. Literature clearly reveals that Lewis and/or Brønsted surface acid sites are important active sites for the SCR reaction [4,28]. Therefore, to examine the surface acidic properties of our catalyst, NH3 was adsorbed on MnOx/TiO2 and the corresponding FT-IR spectra are presented in Fig. 3 . The FT-IR bands after adsorption of NH3 provided information on the nature of acid sites present, while any changes of their characteristics as a function of temperature revealed their strength features. It should be kept in mind that anatase titania possesses pure Lewis acid sites [29]. In the figure, a strong peak at 1164cm−1 can be attributed to δs(NH3) coordinated to Lewis acid sites. The band at 1304cm−1 could also be assigned to δs(NH3) whereas another band at 1599cm−1 is attributed to δas(NH3) coordinated to Lewis acid sites [30,31]. Besides, bands in the high wavenumber region at 3147 and 3248cm−1 are assigned to ν s(NH3), and the band at 3359cm−1 is due to ν as(NH3) coordinated to Lewis acid sites [29,32]. One very weak peak at 1428cm−1 was ascribed to Brønsted acid sites bound δas(NH4 +) vibrations. This peak probably results due to the presence of impurities on the support because manganese has not been known to generate Brønsted acid sites [29,33]. This peak is observed in the case of spectra collected at 50°C. However, the intensity of the peak completely lost when temperature was raised to 200°C. Therefore, it can be suggested that the surface Lewis acid sites are going to play the role as the active sites for the reaction. In situ FT-IR experiments were conducted over 10wt.% MnOx/TiO2 catalyst to identify the possible reaction intermediates and to propose a probable reaction mechanism (pathway). The adsorption and co-adsorption of different gases, such as CO, NO, O2 and carefully selected mixtures of these gases in conjunction with in situ FT-IR spectroscopy was used to elucidate the reaction mechanism as the samples were heated from 50 to 200°C. The in situ FT-IR spectra of the 10wt.% MnOx/TiO2 catalyst after adsorption of NO are shown in Fig. 4 . The introduction of NO led to the formation of a number of peaks that can be basically attributed to the formation of two types of nitrates on the surface of the materials tested, namely, monodentate and bidentate nitrates. The peaks at 1257, 1304, and 1476cm−1 could be assigned to monodentate nitrate species, while the remaining peaks at 1590 and 1644cm−1 are attributed to bidentate nitrate species [34]. However, London et al. made principal assumptions of the SCR of NO mechanism by CO are that NO dissociates upon adsorption, that N2O acts as an intermediate to the formation of N2 over the Cu- based materials [35]. For this reason, we have deconvoluted the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 5 ) to ensure the formation of surface N2O species during the NO adsorption and NO+O2 co-adsorption over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. To better understand the formation of intermediate species and their relative intensities, the overlapped obsorption peaks were deconvoluted into several sub-bands by searching for the optimal combination of Gaussian bands with the correlation coefficients (r2) above 0.99 without fixing the sub-band positions. The selection of number and shape of the peaks to be fitted to each of the original profiles was not arbitrary. One can see from Fig. 5, the low intensity peaks at 1286, 1335cm−1 are evident, which can be ascribed to N2Oads species over the surface of the MnOx/TiO2. Our results are consistent with the literature, where the authors have proposed the SCR of NO mechanism by the formation of surface N2O species [35–38]. The absorption band at 1632cm−1 region (1617cm−1 in the gas phase) was not observed which corresponds to the asymmetric stretching of coordinatively held NO2 [39,40]. To support this occurrence, no signal was observed for NO2 as a gas phase stable product in the mass spectrum during the reaction of NO+O2 over 10wt.% MnOx/TiO2 catalyst at the reaction temperatures. With these in situ FT-IR experiments and mass spectrum analysis it could be evident that NO is converting into N2O but not into NO2 even in the presence of excess oxygen. The in situ FT-IR spectra of the catalyst after adsorption of NO+O2 are also shown in Fig. 4. It is evident that neither the peak positions nor the intensities of the peaks changed significantly in the presence of oxygen. Therefore, the nitrate species observed in this work suggest that lattice oxygen from the surface of the catalyst rather than gas phase oxygen plays an important role in the formation of nitrates. To support this proposal, interaction between the oxygen from the catalyst surface and the gas phase oxygen was investigated using isotopic labeling studies (16O2 was switched to 18O2). The corresponding normalized curves for 16O18O and 18O18O are presented in Fig. 6 . As shown in Fig. 6, when labeled oxygen was passed through the catalyst bed at 200°C, there is an increase of the cross labeled oxygen (16O18O) concentration observed with time. This implies that some oxygen exchange between the gas phase (18O) and lattice oxygen of the catalyst (16O) has taken place. The formation of the cross labeled oxygen from unlabeled gas phase oxygen in the system should be ruled out because the catalyst bed was flushed with helium for one hour following the catalyst pretreatment with 16O2. Moreover, no increase of the signal for unlabeled oxygen (16O2) was observed during the experiment. Based on the above observations it can be suggested that the presence of excess oxygen concentration does not inhibit the NO reduction with CO over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. In other words, excess gas phase oxygen involves in the surface labile oxygen exchange (filling of oxygen vacancies), but does not interfere in the NO reduction reaction by the oxidation of NO+O2 →NO2 and CO+O2 →CO2. The presence of excess oxygen (gas phase oxygen) provide the additional driving force which allows a fast and complete oxidation of the surface of Mn/TiO2. To gain insight for the interaction of various reactants with MnOx/TiO2, transient analysis of products were carried out. During the course of this work NO, CO, N2O, O2 and their selected mixtures were adsorbed on MnOx/TiO2 to examine the interaction of various reactants with the catalyst. Fig. 7 shows the transient response of N2 and O2 in NO and NO+O2 reaction over MnOx/TiO2. Prior to this reaction CO was fed through the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst for (30min) to ensure which type of manganese sites (reduced or oxidized) are required for the NO reduction. From the figure, we could observe the formation of large amounts of nitrogen and oxygen in the first 15min while the concentration of these gases was diminished after 30min. This result clearly suggests that initially CO reduces the catalyst surface and after that, NO is dissociated over a partially reduced surface. This is in agreement with reported results where it has been shown that the adsorbed NO must be dissociated by the partially reduced manganese sites [41]. This phenomena result in the creation of oxygen vacancies by the reducing agent CO (reduction of catalyst surface), the evolved oxygen in the NO decomposition reaction is used to fill these oxygen (surface and bulk) vacancies. For this reason the partial pressure of oxygen is lower than nitrogen in Fig. 7. After introduction of oxygen into the reaction, small increase in the amount of nitrogen was observed. This is due to the surface re-oxidation by the gas phase oxygen. This re-oxidation of the surface is constructive for the reduction of NO into N2O followed by the dissociation of N2O into N2 and Oads. Here, the formation of NO2 was not observed indicating that the NO is not oxidized to nitrogen dioxide even in the presence of excess oxygen. This experiment reveals that NO dissociation is the crucial step in NO+CO reaction over MnOx/TiO2. We have carried out the in situ FT-IR experiments of adsorbed CO over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst and the corresponding spectra are presented in Fig. 8 . No absorption band was observed at around 2150cm−1, which could be attributed to the physically adsorbed CO [10]. Well resolved absorption bands appeared at 1626, 1551cm−1 and in the region of 1432–1250cm−1. The 1551cm−1 (1420–1540cm−1) absorption peak can be ascribed to asymmetric stretching vibration of monodentate carbonate species. Intensity of this peak appears to decrease with increase in temperature. It usually is firmly attached to the surface and decomposes at high-temperatures. The absorption peak at 1343cm−1 (1330–1390cm−1) can be associated to the symmetric stretching vibration of monodentate carbonate coordinated to the surface of Mn/TiO2. The thermal stability is very high for this kind of surface structures. Non-coordinated carbonate species could be identified from the band at 1432cm−1. On the other hand, two distinct peaks at 1626cm−1 and 1301cm−1 can be attributed to a stretching vibration and asymmetric stretching vibration of bidentate carbonates, respectively. The thermal stability of these two bidentate carbonate structures is very low compared to other species. As can be seen from Fig. 8, an absorption peak at 1626cm−1 is highly intensive at 50°C. This indicates that CO adsorption at 50°C exclusively leads to the formation of bidentate carbonate species over MnOx/TiO2 sample. However, the intensity of the carbonate bands at 1626cm−1 and 1301cm−1 was progressively decreased after increasing the temperature to 200°C due to weak thermal stability. We have not observed any absorption peaks in the range of 1780–1840cm−1 accompanying to a wide doublet stretching vibration of bridged carbonate species whereas, the peak at 1251cm−1 (1250–1280cm−1) can be associated to asymmetric stretching vibration of bridged carbonate [42]. A double band centered at 2353cm−1 with significant intensity appears in the spectra. This absorption band is due to CO2 that is formed in the reaction of adsorbed CO and lattice oxygen of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst [43,44]. These observations are suggesting that MnOx/TiO2 catalyst does not release lattice oxygen effectively at 50°C, but it releases lattice oxygen effectively at above 50°C. To examine the effect of excess oxygen on CO adsorption, CO+O2 co-adsorption was also investigated (figure not shown). Like the case of NO+O2 co-adsorption experiments, in this case neither the peak positions nor the intensities of the peaks changed significantly in the presence of oxygen. It should be noted that CO2 formation was evident from the intensity of the doublet peak (at ∼2350cm−1) [43]. The transient response of CO2 in the CO and CO+O2 reaction over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst is presented in Fig. 9 . After introduction of CO to the catalyst, considerable increase in the concentration of CO2 is observed. This is in line with our in situ FT-IR results, which show that in the absence of NO, CO is readily oxidized to CO2. As can be seen from this figure, CO2 formation is high in the first 30min after introduction of CO and gradually decreased. This is due to the reaction of adsorbed CO with the labile lattice oxygen of the catalyst to form CO2. After introduction of oxygen to the reaction stream, a small increase in the CO2 concentration is observed. This is due to the re-oxidation of the catalyst surface by gas phase oxygen. However, CO2 concentration does not increase exponentially after the introduction of oxygen. This indicates that CO is not reacting with the gas phase oxygen to form CO2 but it only reacts with the lattice oxygen of the catalyst. It should be noted that MnOx/TiO2 catalyst is not promoting the CO oxidation reaction in the presence of oxygen. This is one of the reasons for the observed high selectivity of NO+CO reaction in the presence of oxygen over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. NO and CO co-adsorbed in situ FT-IR experiments were carried out to identify the reaction intermediates in the NO+CO reaction. For this purpose, NO was first adsorbed on the catalyst (wafer), flushed with helium, and then CO was introduced or vice-versa. The FT-IR patterns for the NO+CO, and then the CO+NO co-adsorption at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 10 . As one can observe from the figure, the patterns look alike in both cases. The adsorption of NO and CO on MnOx/TiO2 catalyst led to the formation of various adsorption bands in the frequency region of 1200–2600cm−1. Interestingly, when the adsorption of NO is carried out on the CO pre-adsorbed surface (Fig. 10e–h), most of the intense bands are attributed to nitrate species. The peaks at 1245, 1298, and 1483cm−1 could be assigned to monodentate nitrate species. Two peaks at 1583 and 1610cm−1 can be attributed to bidentate nitrate species. The low intensity peak near 1630cm−1 is due to bidentate carbonate formation. This indicates that some portion of adsorbed CO is displaced by NO. When the adsorption of CO was carried out on a NO pre-adsorbed surface (Fig. 10a–d), the patterns are like the previous case. However, the intensity of the band near 2350cm−1 is somewhat increased thus indicating the increased formation of CO2, which may lead to surface reduction. This is as expected while for the 10a-d experiments as a result of NO is pre-adsorbed over the surface of the catalyst, more CO remains in the bulk phase where it is oxidized to CO2. Interestingly, during both CO+NO and NO+CO co-adsorptions, isocyanate (−NCO) peak was not observed neither as a gas phase stable product nor as a surface intermediate, which is one of the advantages of our catalyst. We did not observe any absorption peak around the 2180cm−1 region [10,13–18] in FT-IR spectra, which is ascribed to the pseudo-antisymmetric stretching vibrations of NCO−. Other authors observed the same species over the perovskites [44], metal oxides [15], and noble metals [45]. Based upon this evidence it is proposed that the formation of NCO− species from the reaction between CO and Nads is completely inhibited over the Mn/TiO2 catalysts [46]. Along with the predominant formation of nitrates in the FT-IR spectra, a couple of newly evolved peaks are observed. The low intensity peaks in the frequency region 1755–1992cm−1 are due to adsorbed NO on reduced manganese sites. Newly evolved peaks at 1286 and 1335cm−1 are attributed to the adsorbed N2O [10,15,47]. To verify this observation, we adsorbed N2O on the catalyst surface (Fig. 11 ). As can be seen from the figure, distinct peaks could be observed at 1161, 1190, 1251, 1286, 1337, and 1580cm−1. Therefore, it is clear that N2O is formed during the reaction. The appearance of the peaks at 1286 and 1335cm−1 in the case of NO and CO co-adsorption could be observed when the temperature was raised above 175°C. This allows us to propose that N2O is the intermediate which is formed at or near the reaction temperature. In order to examine the effect of O2 in the reaction, we performed the in situ FT-IR experiment for CO+NO+O2 adsorption and the corresponding spectra are presented in Fig. 12 . The patterns are similar to that obtained in the NO+CO or CO+NO co-adsorption experiment. Here also peaks at 1286 and 1335cm−1 region are clearly observed indicating the formation of N2O as the intermediate. The absorption peak at 1335 has disappeared and the peak at 1298cm−1, attributed to monodentate nitrate, shifts into the peak at 1286cm−1, attributed to N2O. In earlier discussion, we have stated that carbon dioxide formation is observed in the FT-IR studies of CO adsorbed on MnOx/TiO2. Remarkably, as can be seen from Figs. 10 and 12, the intensity of the doublet peak (in the region 2350cm−1) for CO2 is relatively very low thus suggesting that CO oxidation reaction is inhibited in the presence of NO. Another very interesting finding of the present investigation is that we did not observe the formation of isocyanate (–NCO). The later species are reported in the literature as the intermediate on unsupported platinum group metal catalysts in NO+CO reaction [46]. This is confirmed by the absence of a prominent band at the 2178cm−1 frequency region [10]. This observation confirms that the reaction mechanism over the manganese catalyst is different from the reported metal oxide and supported metal catalysts. The negative signal around 1626 and 1551cm−1 indicates the decreasing existence of CO at the interface at above 100°C, coincident with the appearance of newly evolved peaks the peak at 1343 and 1251cm−1 due to symmetric stretching and asymmetric stretching vibrations of bidentate and bridge carbonates [42]. On the other hand, Szanyi et al. stated that as the number of Lewis site-adsorbed CO increases, the intensity of the negative peak increases as well [48,49]. The loss of hydroxyl group stretching vibrations upon the reactant gas adsorption at high temperatures can also be characterized by the negative absorptions [50,51]. Nitric oxide forms surface nitrites and nitrates via dimerization and disproportionation/heterolytic chemisorption, NO produce nitrates by reacting with the surface (labile) oxygen, and the reducing agent enables the rapid and selective decomposition of nitrites to nitrogen over the metal oxide-based catalysts. The nitrate species observed over the surface of Mn/TiO2 can react with CO in the presence of surface Mnn+ sites which mainly exist as Mn4+ and Mn3+ ions [52,53]. The possible reaction route can be depicted as route 1 where the nitrate species act as the intermediates for the NO reduction with CO. Route 1: 2 N O + 2 O 2 ( L a b i l e ) → M n n + 2 N O 3 − → 6 C O M n n + N 2 + 6 C O 2 However, we have not observed disappearance of adsorbed nitrate or carbonate species during the co-adsorption of NO+CO, CO+NO, and CO+NO+O2 over the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. The existence of support sites can stabilize strongly bound surface nitrate species, and carbonate species. The absorption bands at 1245, 1298, and 1483cm−1 region in Fig. 10 could be assigned to monodentate nitrate species adsorbed on TiO2. The low intensity peak near 1630cm−1 is due to bidentate carbonate adsorbed over the support sites. The surface adsorbed nitrate species and carbonate species can block the release of labile oxygen at moderate temperatures. This occurrence seems to be the reason for the CO oxidation inhibition during the reduction of NO reaction over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. These results are in good agreement with the literature reports, where carbon fragments are released directly from the surface or undergo further oxidation to carbon dioxide is closely linked to the sufficiency of oxygen stored in the catalyst [54]. Wenqiao et al. also stated that the accumulated carbonates can block the active sites on the catalyst surface and lead to the reduction in CO oxidation activity [55]. Interestingly, when NO and CO were adsorbed individually on bare TiO2 at wide range of temperatures (50–200°C), some of the absorption peak positions are similar from that of the CO+NO and/or NO+CO co-adsorptions. Distinct peaks at 1160, 1178, 1241–1252, 1287–1294, 1489, 1584cm−1 regions could be observed (Fig. not shown) for NO adsorption. When CO was adsorbed on bare TiO2, very small peaks at 1230, 1275, 1326, 1544 and 1570cm−1 could be observed (figure not shown). Therefore, it is obvious that in the case of CO+NO and/or NO+CO co-adsorptions, CO and NO are not bound to titanium atom. Apparently, it should be bound to Mn. We attempted to find out which oxidation state of the manganese favors the NO and CO surface reactions during the adsorption and co-adsorption of different gases. For this purpose, CO and NO were co-adsorbed on MnO2 and Mn2O3 wafers. The same gas adsorption procedure was followed in these cases as described in the experimental section for our catalyst. Preparation of MnO2 and Mn2O3 could be found elsewhere [22]. Distinct peaks are observed at 1351, 1388, 1412, 1799 and 2201cm−1 for MnO2 sample whereas for Mn2O3 sample, very weak peaks at 1226, 1399, 1796 and 2201cm−1 are detected. Yamashita et al. stated that the Mn2O3 phase is active for the NO decomposition reaction compared Mn3O4 phase [56,57]. As can be seen from Fig. 13 , the peaks are relatively broad in nature and therefore it is difficult to draw a conclusion on the exact role of manganese oxidation state as of this information. From these peak positions and our earlier XPS studies, it can be stated that Mn is present in the both oxidation states (+4 and +3) in our catalyst. These results are consistent with our XPS results of Mn/TiO2 catalyst [52,53,58]. The formation of CO2 is an important step in CO+NO reaction to create an active site for NO dissociation. Adsorbed CO reacts with the adsorbed N2O to form N2 and CO2 by creating two reduced manganese sites (S2), which act as active sites for NO dissociation (Reactions (1)–(3)). In the mechanism, we represent the oxidized catalyst surface as S1, and the reduced Mn sites after CO2 desorption as S2. (1) CO+S1 →*CO (2) (3) From our in situ FT-IR studies we have direct evidences that N2O is formed as the intermediate in the reaction. Therefore, we studied the interaction of N2O and N2O+O2 with MnOx/TiO2 catalyst and analyzed the products with mass spectrometer. Transient response of N2 and NO after adsorption of N2O and N2O+O2 is shown in Fig. 14 . As can be noted from this figure, large amount of nitrogen was produced after the adsorption of N2O in the first 40min. Even after 40min, continuous production of nitrogen could be observed. The production of large amounts of nitrogen, and the NO response behavior could be rationalized with the following explanation. (4) (5) (6) (7) (8) (9) As derived from our results, adsorbed N2O dissociates into nitrogen and adsorbed atomic oxygen (Reaction (4)). Some of the adsorbed nitrous oxide molecules react with the adsorbed atomic oxygen to form nitrogen, and molecular oxygen (Reaction (5)), as well as two molecules of adsorbed nitric oxide (Reaction (6)). Thereafter, adsorbed nitric oxide dissociate on MnOx/TiO2 surface to form molecular nitrogen and oxygen (Reactions (7)–(9)). This might be a reason for the production of large amount of nitrogen compared to NO. When oxygen was introduced into the stream after 90min, a small increase in the nitrogen was observed. This could be due to the re-oxidation of catalyst surface by gas phase oxygen. However, the transient response for NO is not significantly high. After introduction of N2O, there is a small increase in the NO response which is almost constant thereafter. This means, some portion of NO still remains in undissociated form. Based on the above discussion with in situ FT-IR and transient analysis of products, following elementary reactions are proposed for the SCR reaction over MnOx/TiO2 (Scheme 1 ). 4 Conclusions Among different titania supported transition metal-based catalysts, MnOx/TiO2 showed the most promising activity for the SCR of NO with CO as reductant at low temperature. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) study reveals that Lewis acid sites of the catalyst surface are responsible for the reaction rather than Brønsted acid sites. The reduced manganese sites act as the active sites for the activation of NO. The N2O is observed as an intermediate which on subsequent reaction with CO leads to the final product N2. Interestingly, formation of NO2 and isocyanate (–NCO) species were not observed during the present investigations, which are the advantages of our reaction. The lattice oxygen on the surface of the catalyst plays an important role in the reaction, which is confirmed from the isotopic labeling experiment. One remarkable observation is that CO oxidation to CO2 is inhibited in the presence of NO over MnOx/TiO2, which is an important factor for the excellent activity and selectivity of the catalyst. The dissociation of NO occurs over the reduced manganese sites leading to the formation of N2O. The formation of cross labeled oxygen species revealed that the presence of excess oxygen (gas phase) concentration does not inhibit the NO reduction with CO over MnOx/TiO2 catalysts. It is a clear evident from the transient studies of NO and NO+O2 reaction that the adsorbed NO molecules must be dissociated over the partially reduced manganese sites. The re-oxidation of the surface is constructive for the reduction of NO into N2O followed by the dissociation of N2O into N2 and adatom oxygen. The intermediate N2O reduced by the adsorbed CO to produce molecular nitrogen and carbon dioxide. Finally, it can be concluded that NO reduction with CO follows a redox mechanism over MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. Dedicated to Dr. Benjaram Mahipal Reddy on his 60th birthday I had the opportunity to collaborate with Professor Dr. Benjaram Mahipal Reddy throughout his distinguished career, and I am honored to dedicate this paper in a special issue of Molecular Catalysis to celebrate his scientific contributions on his 60th birthday. Professor Benjaram Mahipal Reddy is one of the world’s most influential catalysis scientists. He conducted both theoretical and experimental research, which has improved the understanding of the fundamental phenomena involved in catalysis processes and developed new materials, chemical processes and research methods. I dedicate this paper to him in appreciation of his endless contributions and research in heterogeneous catalysis and material science. coredata.dc:description: A series of titania-supported transition metal oxide catalysts were evaluated for NO reduction with CO as reductant at low temperature (200°C) in the presence of excess oxygen. Among the investigated systems, MnOx/TiO2 has been found to be the preeminent catalyst. In situ FT-IR and transient studies were carried out in order to identify the chemisorbed species which could act as catalytic intermediates, and in consequence to propose the low temperature reduction of NO pathway over the Mn/TiO2. The NO adsorption and NO+O2 co-adsorption of in situ FT-IR experiments revealed the formation of surface reaction intermediate N2O species along with the formation of monodentate and bidentate nitrates, whereas CO adsorption on the catalyst leads to the formation of carbonate species. Interestingly, in the case of NO and CO co-adsorption over MnOx/TiO2, the formation of CO2 (CO oxidation with gas phase oxygen) is inhibited due to the surface reaction competition between NO and CO. The formation of N2O as an intermediate was evident from the occurrence of peaks at 1286 and 1335cm−1 region. There is no formation of NO2 as a surface intermediate or gas phase stable product in the present in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and transient mass spectroscopic studies, respectively. Remarkably, a neat absorption peak at 2178cm−1 ascribed to the isocyanate (–NCO) species was not observed during in situ infrared spectroscopic studies of NO+CO and CO+NO co-adsorptions. Based upon this evidence it is proposed that the formation of NCO− species from the reaction between CO and Nads is completely forbidden over the Mn/TiO2 catalysts. These results indicate that the reaction mechanism follows a different pathway for our catalyst, from that of the other metal based catalysts. The role of lattice oxygen in the reaction mechanism is substantiated by isotopic labeling and transient analysis studies. Lewis acid sites act as the active sites for the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic investigations on NO reduction with CO over Mn/TiO2 catalyst at low temperatures
coredata.prism:issueName: Metal Oxides in Catalysis - Professor Benjaram M. Reddy Festschrift
